headline: Classic Butternut Squash Soup Recipe

author.name: Daniel Gritzer
author.description: Daniel joined the Serious Eats culinary team in 2014 and writes recipes, equipment reviews, articles on cooking techniques. Prior to that he was a food editor at Food & Wine magazine, and the staff writer for Time Out New York's restaurant and bars section.
knowsAbout: General recipe development, Italian, French, Spanish & Jewish food, Food science, Food history, Equipment reviews

description: The most flavorful butternut squash soup, made by roasting the squash until it's deeply browned and caramelized.
name: Classic Butternut Squash Soup Recipe
keywords: butternut squash, essential, fall, low carb, soup, squash, winter, winter squash
recipeIngredient: 1 (2 1/2–pound; 1kg) butternut squash, peeled, seeded, and cut into 1-inch cubes
1 large (8-ounce; 215g) carrot, peeled and cut into 1-inch chunks
4 cups (1L) homemade or store-bought low-sodium chicken or vegetable stock, plus more as needed
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 425°F (230°C). Toss squash and carrot with olive oil and arrange on 2 rimmed baking sheets, being sure not to overcrowd the sheets. Roast until squash and carrot are very well browned on a couple of sides, about 40 minutes; use a thin metal spatula to turn pieces 2 or 3 times during cooking. Set aside.

In a large saucepan, cook 2 tablespoons butter over medium-high heat until just starting to brown. Add onion and garlic, lower heat to medium, and cook, stirring, until soft and lightly golden, about 10 minutes; lower heat as necessary to prevent burning.

Add squash and carrot to saucepan and remove from heat. Pour 1/2 cup (120ml) stock into each baking sheet and scrape up any browned bits, then pour into saucepan. Add remaining stock, thyme sprigs, and bay leaf and return to medium-high heat. Bring to a simmer, then lower heat and simmer until vegetables are very soft, about 10 minutes. Discard thyme sprigs and bay leaf.

Using a high-powered blender , standard countertop blender or immersion blender , blend soup until completely smooth. Season with salt and pepper. Return soup to saucepan and thin, if necessary, with additional stock until desired consistency is reached. Keep warm.
Meanwhile, in a stand mixer, or using a handheld mixer or whisk, beat cream and sour cream with cinnamon, nutmeg, and a pinch of salt, until stiff. Set aside.

If making frizzled sage leaves, melt remaining 5 tablespoons butter in a small skillet over medium-high heat, swirling gently, until foamy and just beginning to brown. Add sage leaves, swirling to submerge, and cook until frizzled, about 15 seconds. Using a slotted spoon, transfer sage to a paper towel to drain. Sprinkle very lightly with salt.
Ladle soup into warmed bowls, spoon dollops of spiced whipped cream into each one, and top with frizzled sage, if using. Serve right away.

review.reviewBody:
I've made this several times, and I love the roasting option. I've boiled the squash in the past, and you get an okay soup, but it can't touch the depth of flavor here. 

I've noticed that my roasting time always ends up much higher (closer to an hour to get to browned bits on the edges). I suspect three things: (1) I'm probably making my pieces closer to 1.5in; (2) I put them all on one sheet, which though very large and not crowded, probably still inhibits browning a bit; and (3) I think my oven runs a little low (time to buy an oven thermometer!)

I also like to add some vinegar (balsamic, sherry) along with salt and pepper in final tasting before serving. Gives it a little extra zip, which balances the sweet, earthy squash flavor.
I roasted onion and garlic with the butternut and carrots and that worked out fine instead of cooking them separately. Very easy recipe to make and tastes very good.

I always add some Indian spices to mine during cooking (cumin, coriander, turmeric, cayenne, cinnamon, clove, fenugreek, fennel etc.) or just some ready made curry powder or garam masala....gives it some real warmth and character

I made this soup for the first time after years of devotion to the original version. Both are great recipes! I loved the addition of the spices, sage, and the whipped cream. Next time I’ll add a bit of the sage browned butter to the final soup assembly. I also can’t wait to try some of the variations suggested in other comments. 

Tip that is probably obvious to others but not to me - the immersion blender does a better job whipping cream in the cup not a bowl.
I'm in the process of making the soup, and I'm using Trader Joe's diced butternut squash. It took only twenty minutes to brown, not forty.
